Tipping in Mexico: The Complete Guide

Who to Tip, How Much, and When—Without the Awkwardness

Last updated: January 2025

Tipping in Mexico follows different rules than the US, Canada, or Europe—and the rules change depending on whether you're at an all-inclusive resort, a local taco stand, or a fine dining restaurant. This guide eliminates the guesswork so you can tip appropriately without anxiety or accidentally insulting anyone.

In This Guide

  • Tipping Fundamentals
  • Restaurant Tipping
  • All-Inclusive Resort Tipping
  • Hotel Tipping (Non All-Inclusive)
  • Transportation Tipping
  • Service Provider Tipping
  • When NOT to Tip
  • Tipping Etiquette
  • Cash & Currency Tips
  • Quick Reference Cheat Sheet

Tipping Fundamentals

{<strong>The Basics:</strong></p><p>- Tipping is customary in Mexico but generally lower than US percentages</p><ul><li>Service workers often earn minimum wage (~$15 USD/day), so tips matter</p><ul><li>Cash tips are preferred—they go directly to the worker</p><ul><li>Pesos preferred, but US dollars accepted in tourist areas</p><ul><li>"Propina" is Spanish for tip</p><p><strong>Pesos vs Dollars:</strong></p><p><strong>Use Pesos When:</strong></p><ul><li>At local restaurants and street food</p><ul><li>For taxi drivers</p><ul><li>At non-tourist businesses</p><ul><li>For small tips (porters, housekeeping)</p><ul><li>When you want the worker to get full value</p><p><strong>Dollars Acceptable When:</strong></p><ul><li>At all-inclusive resorts</p><ul><li>In heavily touristed areas (Cancún, Cabo)</p><ul><li>For tour guides</p><ul><li>When you don't have pesos available</p><p><strong>Exchange Rate Awareness:</strong> At roughly 17 pesos = $1 USD, a $1 tip equals about 17 pesos. A 50-peso tip equals about $3 USD. Know the rough rate so you don't over or under-tip.}

Restaurant Tipping

{<strong>Standard Restaurants:</strong></p><p>| Service Level | Tip Amount | |--------------|------------| | Average service | 10-15% | | Good service | 15-18% | | Exceptional service | 20% | | Poor service | 5-10% (still expected) |</p><p><strong>Important Notes:</strong></p><ul><li>Check if "servicio" or "propina" is already included (rare but happens)</p><ul><li>Tip on pre-tax amount</p><ul><li>Cash preferred even when paying by card</p><ul><li>If paying by card, you can add tip to receipt OR leave cash</p><p><strong>Fine Dining:</strong></p><ul><li>15-20% standard</p><ul><li>Some upscale restaurants include service charge</p><ul><li>Always check the bill</p><p><strong>Casual/Local Restaurants:</strong></p><ul><li>10-15% is appropriate</p><ul><li>Rounding up is acceptable for small bills</p><ul><li>Taco stands: not expected but appreciated (5-10 pesos)</p><p><strong>Street Food:</strong></p><ul><li>Not expected at taco stands or food carts</p><ul><li>Leaving coins (5-10 pesos) is kind but optional</p><ul><li>If there's table service, 10% appropriate</p><p><strong>Bars:</strong></p><ul><li>10-15 pesos per drink, or 10-15% of tab</p><ul><li>Running a tab? Tip at the end</p><ul><li>Craft cocktails warrant higher tips}

All-Inclusive Resort Tipping

{<strong>The Big Question: Do You Tip at All-Inclusives?</strong></p><p>Yes—gratuities are "included" in your rate, but that money goes to the resort, not directly to staff. Tipping cash ensures workers benefit directly and usually improves your service.</p><p><strong>Daily Budget:</strong></p><ul><li>Budget approach: $10-15 USD/day total</p><ul><li>Standard approach: $20-30 USD/day total</p><ul><li>Generous approach: $40-50 USD/day total</p><p><strong>Who to Tip:</strong></p><p><strong>Housekeeping: $2-5 USD/day</strong></p><ul><li>Leave daily (different staff may clean)</p><ul><li>Leave on pillow or nightstand with note "Gracias"</p><ul><li>More for larger suites or extra requests</p><p><strong>Waiters at Restaurants: $2-5 per meal</strong></p><ul><li>Buffet service: $1-2</p><ul><li>À la carte dinner: $3-5</p><ul><li>Exceptional service: $5-10</p><p><strong>Bartenders: $1-2 per drink or round</strong></p><ul><li>Order multiple drinks? Tip once per round</p><ul><li>Swim-up bar: same rules apply</p><ul><li>Tip early for better service all week</p><p><strong>Pool/Beach Attendants: $2-5</strong></p><ul><li>When they set up chairs/umbrellas</p><ul><li>Once per day is sufficient</p><ul><li>More for prime locations or extra service</p><p><strong>Room Service: $2-3 per delivery</strong></p><ul><li>Even though it's "free"</p><ul><li>Tip upon delivery</p><p><strong>Concierge: $5-20</strong></p><ul><li>For restaurant reservations: $5</p><ul><li>For special arrangements: $10-20</p><ul><li>For solving problems: $10-20</p><p><strong>Bellhop/Porter: $1-2 per bag</strong></p><ul><li>At arrival and departure</p><ul><li>Minimum $5 for large loads</p><p><strong>Pro Tip:</strong> Bring a stack of $1 and $5 bills. Small denomination makes daily tipping easy.}

Hotel Tipping (Non All-Inclusive)

{<strong>Boutique Hotels & Standard Hotels:</strong></p><p><strong>Bellhop/Porter:</strong></p><ul><li>$1-2 USD per bag (20-40 pesos)</p><ul><li>Minimum $2-3 for one bag</p><ul><li>More for heavy or numerous bags</p><p><strong>Housekeeping:</strong></p><ul><li>$2-5 USD per night (40-100 pesos)</p><ul><li>Leave daily, not just at checkout</p><ul><li>More for suites or extra cleaning</p><p><strong>Concierge:</strong></p><ul><li>$5-10 for restaurant reservations</p><ul><li>$10-20 for tickets, tours, special requests</p><ul><li>$20+ for solving significant problems</p><p><strong>Valet Parking:</strong></p><ul><li>$2-3 each time car is retrieved (40-60 pesos)</p><ul><li>Tip when receiving car, not when dropping off</p><p><strong>Room Service:</strong></p><ul><li>15-20% of bill</p><ul><li>Check if gratuity included</p><ul><li>Cash preferred</p><p><strong>Doorman:</strong></p><ul><li>$1-2 for hailing taxi</p><ul><li>Not required for simply opening door</p><p><strong>Spa:</strong></p><ul><li>15-20% of treatment cost</p><ul><li>Cash to therapist directly preferred</p><ul><li>Can add to room charge if necessary}

Transportation Tipping

{<strong>Taxis:</strong></p><p><strong>Regular Taxis:</strong></p><ul><li>Tipping not strictly expected</p><ul><li>Round up to nearest 10 pesos</p><ul><li>$1-2 USD for exceptional service</p><ul><li>Tip more if they help with luggage</p><p><strong>Airport Taxis:</strong></p><ul><li>10-15% or round up</p><ul><li>Fixed-rate zones: round up</p><ul><li>Long rides: 10% of fare</p><p><strong>Uber/Didi:</strong></p><ul><li>Tipping optional (in-app available)</p><ul><li>10-15% for good service</p><ul><li>Cash tip always appreciated</p><p><strong>Private Transfers:</strong></p><ul><li>$5-10 USD for standard transfer</p><ul><li>$10-20 USD for luxury/long transfers</p><ul><li>More for multiple stops or help with luggage</p><p><strong>Rental Car:</strong></p><ul><li>No tip required</p><ul><li>$2-3 to attendant if they help extensively</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Tours & Guides:</strong></p><p><strong>Day Tour Guide:</strong></p><ul><li>$5-10 USD per person for half-day</p><ul><li>$10-20 USD per person for full day</p><ul><li>More for exceptional guides</p><p><strong>Private Guide:</strong></p><ul><li>$20-50 USD for full day</p><ul><li>15-20% of tour cost is reasonable</p><ul><li>They remember generous tippers</p><p><strong>Boat Captains/Crew:</strong></p><ul><li>$5-10 per person for day trips</p><ul><li>Split between captain and crew</p><ul><li>More for fishing charters (15-20%)</p><p><strong>Snorkel/Dive Guides:</strong></p><ul><li>$5-10 per person</p><ul><li>$10-20 for exceptional guides</p><ul><li>They often provide extra attention for tippers</p><p><strong>Driver (Tour Bus):</strong></p><ul><li>$2-5 per person</p><ul><li>Separate from guide tip</p><ul><li>Collected at end of tour}

Service Provider Tipping

{<strong>Spa & Wellness:</strong></p><p>| Service | Tip Amount | |---------|------------| | Massage (60 min) | 15-20% (~$10-20) | | Facial | 15-20% | | Mani/pedi | 15-20% | | Hair salon | 15-20% | | Temazcal ceremony | $10-20 per person |</p><p><strong>Note:</strong> At resort spas, gratuity may be auto-added—check your bill.</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Activities & Recreation:</strong></p><p><strong>Golf:</strong></p><ul><li>Caddie: $20-40 per round</p><ul><li>Cart attendant: $2-3</p><ul><li>Bag handler: $2-3</p><p><strong>Fishing Charter:</strong></p><ul><li>15-20% of charter cost</p><ul><li>Split captain (60%) and mate (40%)</p><ul><li>Minimum $50-100 for full-day charter</p><p><strong>Horseback Riding:</strong></p><ul><li>$5-10 per person to guide</p><p><strong>Zip-lining/Adventure Parks:</strong></p><ul><li>$2-5 per guide</p><ul><li>Not always expected but appreciated</p><p><strong>Cenote Guides:</strong></p><ul><li>$3-5 per person</p><ul><li>More for private tours</p><p>---</p><p><strong>Other Services:</strong></p><p><strong>Gas Station Attendants:</strong></p><ul><li>10-20 pesos ($0.50-1) if they wash windows, check tires</p><ul><li>Not required for just pumping gas</p><p><strong>Grocery Baggers:</strong></p><ul><li>10-20 pesos</p><ul><li>They work for tips only (no salary)</p><ul><li>Always tip grocery baggers</p><p><strong>Parking Lot Attendants:</strong></p><ul><li>10-20 pesos</p><ul><li>They often watch your car</p><ul><li>Tip when leaving</p><p><strong>Musicians/Performers:</strong></p><ul><li>20-50 pesos for tableside performance</p><ul><li>50-100 pesos if you request a song}

When NOT to Tip

{<strong>Tipping Not Expected:</strong></p><p>- <strong>Fast food restaurants</strong> - Counter service, no tip</p><ul><li><strong>Convenience stores</strong> - Not customary</p><ul><li><strong>Street vendors</strong> - Price is price, no tip</p><ul><li><strong>Self-service situations</strong> - No service, no tip</p><ul><li><strong>Government offices</strong> - Never tip officials</p><ul><li><strong>Police</strong> - Never (this would be a bribe)</p><ul><li><strong>Bus drivers (public transit)</strong> - Not customary</p><ul><li><strong>Business transactions</strong> - Not appropriate</p><p><strong>Tipping Optional:</strong></p><p>- <strong>Taco stands</strong> - Kind gesture but not expected</p><ul><li><strong>Coffee shops (counter service)</strong> - Round up or tip jar</p><ul><li><strong>Uber/Didi</strong> - Optional in-app</p><ul><li><strong>Pharmacy</strong> - Not customary</p><p><strong>Cultural Note:</strong> Mexicans don't tip as heavily as Americans for casual service. Following local custom (10-15%) is appropriate—you don't need to tip American percentages (20%+) everywhere.}

Tipping Etiquette

{<strong>How to Tip Gracefully:</strong></p><p><strong>At Restaurants:</strong></p><ul><li>Place cash in bill folder or hand directly</p><ul><li>Say "Quédese con el cambio" (Keep the change)</p><ul><li>Or simply "Gracias" with a smile</p><ul><li>Don't make a show of calculating</p><p><strong>At Hotels:</strong></p><ul><li>Leave housekeeping tip visible on pillow or nightstand</p><ul><li>Hand tips directly to porters</p><ul><li>Use envelope if tip is significant</p><p><strong>For Service Providers:</strong></p><ul><li>Tip at end of service</p><ul><li>Hand directly when possible</p><ul><li>Brief eye contact and "Gracias" is sufficient</p><ul><li>No need for elaborate praise</p><p><strong>Awkward Situations:</strong></p><p><strong>Poor Service:</strong></p><ul><li>Still tip (5-10%), but reduce amount</p><ul><li>Service workers often aren't to blame for kitchen issues</p><ul><li>Speak to management separately if needed</p><p><strong>Unsure If Tip Included:</strong></p><ul><li>Ask: "¿Está incluida la propina?"</p><ul><li>Check bill for "servicio" or "propina" line</p><ul><li>When in doubt, tip anyway (they'll appreciate it)</p><p><strong>Don't Have Correct Change:</strong></p><ul><li>Ask: "¿Tiene cambio?" (Do you have change?)</p><ul><li>$20 bills often hard to break</p><ul><li>Bring small bills specifically for tips}

Cash & Currency Tips

{<strong>Best Practices:</strong></p><p><strong>Before Your Trip:</strong></p><ul><li>Get $50-100 USD in small bills ($1, $5)</p><ul><li>Or exchange $100-200 for pesos at bank</p><ul><li>Avoid airport exchange (bad rates)</p><p><strong>During Your Trip:</strong></p><ul><li>Use ATMs for best peso exchange rate</p><ul><li>Keep tip money separate from spending money</p><ul><li>Small bills always—$50 and $100 peso notes ideal</p><ul><li>US $1 bills work at resorts</p><p><strong>Carrying Tip Money:</strong></p><ul><li>Pocket for daily tips</p><ul><li>Hotel safe for reserve</p><ul><li>Don't flash large amounts</p><ul><li>Know what denominations you have</p><p><strong>Pesos You'll Use for Tips:</strong></p><ul><li>20 peso coin (~$1.15 USD)</p><ul><li>50 peso note (~$3 USD)</p><ul><li>100 peso note (~$6 USD)</p><ul><li>200 peso note (~$12 USD)</p><p><strong>Exchange Math (approximate):</strong> | Pesos | USD | |-------|-----| | 20 | $1.15 | | 50 | $3 | | 100 | $6 | | 200 | $12 | | 500 | $30 |}

Quick Reference Cheat Sheet

{<strong>Print or Screenshot This:</strong></p><p><strong>Restaurants:</strong></p><ul><li>Casual: 10-15%</p><ul><li>Fine dining: 15-20%</p><ul><li>Street food: Not required</p><p><strong>All-Inclusive Daily:</strong></p><ul><li>Housekeeping: $3-5</p><ul><li>Waiters: $2-5/meal</p><ul><li>Bartenders: $1-2/drink</p><ul><li>Pool staff: $2-5</p><p><strong>Hotels:</strong></p><ul><li>Bellhop: $1-2/bag</p><ul><li>Housekeeping: $3-5/night</p><ul><li>Concierge: $5-20</p><ul><li>Valet: $2-3</p><p><strong>Transportation:</strong></p><ul><li>Taxi: Round up or 10%</p><ul><li>Private transfer: $5-10</p><ul><li>Tour guide: $10-20/day</p><ul><li>Boat crew: $5-10/person</p><p><strong>Spa:</strong></p><ul><li>All services: 15-20%</p><p><strong>Always Tip:</strong></p><ul><li>Grocery baggers: 10-20 pesos</p><ul><li>Gas attendants (extra service): 10-20 pesos</p><ul><li>Parking attendants: 10-20 pesos</p><p><strong>Never Tip:</strong></p><ul><li>Police or officials</p><ul><li>Counter service fast food</p><ul><li>Bus drivers (public)}

Frequently Asked Questions

Do I really need to tip at all-inclusive resorts?

Technically no—gratuities are included in your rate. But those pooled tips don't always reach workers directly, and cash tips improve your service noticeably. Budget $15-30 USD/day for tips, and you'll have better drinks, faster service, and premium beach chairs mysteriously appearing.

Should I tip in pesos or dollars?

Pesos are preferred at local establishments and ensure workers get full value without exchange hassles. US dollars are fine at resorts and tourist areas—$1 bills are basically universal in Cancún and Cabo. When in doubt, pesos show cultural awareness and are always appreciated.

What if service is really bad—do I still tip?

Yes, reduce the tip to 5-10% but still leave something. Service workers earn very low base wages. Address serious issues with management separately. The exception: genuinely offensive or inappropriate behavior warrants no tip and a complaint.

How do I tip if I'm paying by credit card?

You can write the tip on the receipt, but cash is always preferred—it goes directly to the worker without delay or potential skimming. Best approach: pay bill on card, leave cash tip on table. Second best: add tip to card receipt.

Is it true grocery baggers work only for tips?

Yes—in most Mexican supermarkets, baggers (often elderly or students) receive no salary and work entirely for tips. Always tip 10-20 pesos per bag or more for large loads. This is one tip you should never skip.
